physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Open wound on the volar surface of the distal part of the left forearm. Painful swelling of the forearm. Fingers contracted in an intrinsic-minus position. Limited active finger motion with only a few degrees of painful passive extension. Radial and ulnar pulses not felt due to extensive swelling. Decreased sensation in the median nerve distribution.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Swollen area spontaneously opened and drained for ten days prior to presentation.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Radiographs showed soft-tissue swelling with subperiosteal new bone formation, cortical erosion, and lytic lesions in the distal third of the radius and ulna.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Two and a half years postoperatively, the pseudotumor had resolved, and there was a mild residual fixed flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the index finger.
